metadata.title: TikTok’s algorithms knew I was bi before I did. I’m not the only one.

metadata.title: An anniversary for great justice: Remembering “All Your Base” 20 years later
metadata.description: Back in our day, memes didn’t benefit from centralized services like YouTube, Twitter.
metadata.author: Sam Machkovech

metadata.title: 25 years ago today, the internet declared its independence — for better and for worse
metadata.description: Tech utopianism and tech hubris appear more thoroughly intertwined today than ever, and John Perry Barlow’s cyberlibertarian visions echo in the policy debates of today.
metadata.author: Joshua Benton

metadata.title: Jay Ford: My Camera, My Voice - SmugMug Films

sections: The TikTok Algorithm sees into your soul
Because it's build around a way of making you express your most promal self without consequence…
The TikTok algo is still failing to “get” me after months of trying. That may say more about me than it does about the service, though…
All Your Base Are Belong To Us Old Folks
One of the very oldest internet memes hit 20 years old earlier in the month. Here's a great history of that moment:

Watching it now, 20 years later, the thing that stands out to me most is how culturally dated the video feels. It’s from the era of internet culture when the whole joke was getting the reference; back then, the internet was much harder to access and not the kind of culture-defining trend machine it eventually became. Knowing the reference — and sneaking it in places it didn’t belong — was funny because not everyone could figure out what it meant, unless, of course, you were part of the tribe.
I miss the time when there was a distinct seperation between internet culture and general culture. The blending of the two has not been kind to either.
The Impossibility of an Independent Cyberspace
While we're on the subject of restrofuturistic nostalgia, this takedown of John Perry Barlow's famour
A Declaration of the Independence of Cyberspace
is, perhaps, unduly harsh — but still accurate.
There's not much “for better” to be found in the article, but I truly miss the age when the internet was a place where this seemed liek a good idea.
